title: 108_hr984
content:
The Act is titled the "National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Act of 2003" and defines key terms like Administration, function, office, Secretary, and Under Secretary. It also outlines the organization of the Administration. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, under the Department of Commerce, has primary missions including providing hydrographic and geodetic products, conserving coastal and marine resources, exploring oceans and Great Lakes, advancing human understanding of oceans, atmosphere, and their relationship, and forecasting weather and climate. The Administration includes components like the National Coast and Ocean Service. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration includes components such as the National Coast and Ocean Service, National Oceanic and Atmospheric Research Service, National Marine Fisheries Service, National Weather Service, National Environmental Satellite and Data Information Service, and the Office of Marine and Aviation Operations. The Administration performs functions previously vested in it or its officers, employees, or offices, unless otherwise provided by law or redelegated by authorized officials. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration performs functions previously vested in it or its officers, employees, or offices, unless otherwise provided by law or redelegated by authorized officials. SEC. 4. UNDER SECRETARY FOR OCEANS AND ATMOSPHERE. The Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere is appointed by the President with Senate approval and is responsible for managing the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, including general management, policy development, budget formulation, and resource allocation. The Under Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere is responsible for managing the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, including resource allocation, program management, personnel supervision, procurement of services, external affairs, and administration of contracts and facilities. SEC. 5. ASSISTANT SECRETARY FOR OCEANS AND ATMOSPHERE.

There shall be an Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Oceans and Atmosphere appointed by the President with Senate approval. The Assistant Secretary will be paid at level IV of the Executive Schedule and will perform functions as prescribed by the Secretary or Under Secretary, acting as Under Secretary when necessary.

SEC. 6. DEPUTY UNDER SECRETARY. The Deputy Under Secretary for Oceans and Atmosphere is appointed by the Secretary and serves as an advisor on program and policy issues, ensures timely implementation of policies, and acts in the absence of the Under Secretary or Assistant Secretary. In the absence of the Under Secretary or Assistant Secretary, the Deputy Under Secretary for Oceans and Atmosphere will act in that position. SEC. 7. GENERAL COUNSEL. The General Counsel, appointed by the Secretary, serves as the chief legal officer of the Administration and performs other functions as prescribed by the Secretary or Under Secretary. SEC. 8. ASSISTANT ADMINISTRATORS. The Administration includes Assistant Administrators for Coastal and Ocean Services, Oceanic and Atmospheric Research, Fisheries, Weather, Environmental Satellite Data and Information, Program Planning and Integration, and a Director of Marine and Aviation Operations appointed by the Secretary. Each position is a Senior Executive Service general position. Each Assistant Administrator and the Director must be qualified to direct their functions under the authority of the Under Secretary as per the relevant section of the United States Code. SEC. 9. CONTINUATION OF SERVICE. Any individual serving in a position provided for in this Act may continue until a successor is appointed. SEC. 10. SCIENCE ADVISORY BOARD. The Science Advisory Board in the Administration advises the Under Secretary on research, education, and application of science for resource management and environmental assessment. Members are appointed to ensure a balanced representation of scientists, engineers, educators, industry, and science policy experts. Standard criteria are developed for member selection. Members of the Science Advisory Board serve for a 3-year term, may be reappointed once, and are subject to ethical standards. They are not compensated but may receive travel expenses. The Science Advisory Board members serve a 3-year term, are subject to ethical standards, and receive travel expenses. The Under Secretary designates a Chairperson, the Board meets twice a year, and administrative support is provided. SEC. 11. GENERAL AUTHORITIES. The Secretary of the Administration can enter into grants, contracts, or cooperative agreements with various entities and accept funds from them. Resource sharing agreements can also be made with States, local governments, or Federal agencies for the use of personnel, services, equipment, or facilities on different bases. The Secretary of the Administration can establish joint or cooperative institutes with colleges, universities, and research organizations for long-term research programs in various areas such as oceanography, climate change, and marine technology. The Secretary of the Administration can establish joint or cooperative institutes with colleges, universities, and research organizations for long-term research programs in various areas such as oceanography, climate change, marine technology, estuarine environmental technology, fisheries, hydrography, and marine spill response. The Secretary may provide facilities, personnel, equipment, property, knowledge, scientific research resources, and funds for such institutes on a reimbursable or nonreimbursable basis. SEC. 12. PROGRAM SUPPORT. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to appropriate funds for corporate services, marine operations, maintenance, and facilities for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration for fiscal years 2004 through 2008. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is allocated $20,000,000 annually from 2004 to 2008 for maintenance, repair, safety, and project planning of facilities. SEC. 13. NOAA Fleet Replacement and Modernization. Amends Section 603 of the NOAA Fleet Modernization Act to establish a Fleet Replacement and Modernization Program. The Secretary may implement a program to replace and modernize the NOAA fleet, with restrictions on foreign construction unless authorized by the President for national security reasons. The Congress receives the Fleet Modernization Plan amendment under the NOAA Fleet Modernization Act. The Congress receives the Fleet Modernization Plan amendment under the NOAA Fleet Modernization Act. SEC. 604 outlines the Fleet Modernization Plan. The Secretary must submit a modernization plan for the NOAA fleet to Congress within 30 days of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Act of 2003. The plan should include details on vessels to be modernized or replaced, construction, leasing, funding requirements, and utilization of UNOLS vessels. The NOAA Fleet Modernization Act requires the Secretary to submit a plan for modernizing the fleet, including details on vessel availability, acquisition of scientific instrumentation, and use of UNOLS vessels. SEC. 605 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Act allows the Secretary to use excess capacity of UNOLS vessels for NOAA missions and enter agreements with vessel operators. Sections 607, 608, 609, and 610 of the NOAA Fleet Modernization Act are repealed. SEC. 14 of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Act includes amendments to the pay rate of the Deputy Under Secretary and repeals Reorganization Plan Number 4 of 1970.
